title: Which Republican presidential candidate will win the Ohio primary on 15 March?
preds: I think Rubio has a better chance than Kasich, but very little chance of actually winning. People like Trump because he's like Cruz, but more extreme so I think he'll get the primary.
Kasich won Ohio today and gave a nice victory speech.
I still can't believe it, but it looks like he's edging out Trump. Still, one never knows. Projections aren't certain.
kasich claiming tide has turned.  only 88 pc of rest of votes to go.
Ohio has been called for Governor Kasich.
Ted cruz will most probably win

I am wary because Trump voters seem inclined to lie about their preference for him, underreporting their intension. They're embarrassed to vote for him. This is seen in the consistent under-estimating of Trump's plurality. This is why my estimate for P(Kasich) is low compared to the probability the polls would give him. Kruz and Rubio together couldn't have P(win) higher than a few percent.
It is going to be very close but Ohio is John Kasich's home state therefore his chances of beating Trump are close but possible.

Ohio is an open primary. That's prime Trump territory. http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/03/can_i_change_my_party_affiliat.html
15.6% of D's voting R in absentee from Cuyahoga County, point toward Trump. Still the polling has trended Kasich. Lots of numbers, I'm going with the bigger trending ones.
Trump insulted Ohio voters already, Kasich is a known quantity.  Cruz will play better among suburban conservatives than Rubio.
Late deciders likely go for Kasich

There hasn't been a significant poll showing a lead for Donald J. Trump in Ohio in over a week. Polls suggest Governor Kasich holds a narrow but meaningful lead in the state. While a fairly close margin -- roughly five percentage points -- looks likely, one can expect that edge to favor Governor Kasich.
Scared by rally Trump.  Vote for K
Updating to reflect (1) the new 538 odds of 74% and (2) the belated realization that Kasich, as a sitting governor, probably has a great GOTV operation and is likely to overperform his polls.

Up by 4 points averages over 6 polls.  Std. Error is about 4 in each, averages probably about 2 in the aggregate for a standard error.  Chance Kasich is 2 points lower or more is about 15%.  If he goes down 2 points, Trump probably goes up by most of 2%, but probably not quite enough to win.  So call it 10% chance Trump is really in the lead and polls are sampling wrong.  Kasich is very well known in Ohio, so late breakers should already know if they want to vote for him.  Same issue with Trump, I think he does not do well with late breakers.  Lastly, Kasich has momentum so this may mean late breakers side with him.  Trump weekend kerfuffle probably makes him weaker and polls may have missed some of that.  Bump Kasich up a little, but I'm disinclined to go much above 90, especially given polling errors in Michigan, so I'll stay at 90 or maybe even move down a little.  1% for Cruze seems too generous, but then I remember the Michigan polling disaster.
Looks like JK is getting ahead.... Going with the flow on this one. Switching places:
Kasich has the edge in recent polls.

The average Trump voter and supporter is a white person without education that is surprised Canada has people living in it, a very angry population that is easy to manipulate by advertising slogans. 
Ohio on the other hand is highly ranked state among quality of public libraries, has world renowned Universities a progressive community and arts, home to some specialized companies in transportation and pharmaceutical industries which require certain levels of higher education and leads to high gdp and being 7th largest state makes it a strong candidate this early in the elections. 
Trump has his black swans in any state though.

Kasich maybe not be the winning candidate in the elections so far, but his efforts in Ohio as a governor pay off now in the numbers of supporters. Rubio's supporters flocked to Kasich as well. Trump's media frenzy and the anti Trump movement created an opposite effect and an opportunity for people. To be exposed to Trump, the fact that his name is more searched on Google than any of the other candidates.

Since this IFP has been live since March 4th, most of our scores are already baked in (I've had Kasich in the 70s for about half the time and Trump in the 70s for about half the time). As a result, I thought I'd be a little cavalier with my forecast here. I've been seeing the headlines, just as all of you have about Kasich pulling ahead (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_republican_presidential_primary-4077.html#polls), but there's something about this that doesn't quite feel right to me. Even 538's preview of tomorrow (http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/florida-ohio-republican-primary-preview/) doesn't seem to really give us any new/extra information about Ohio. PredictIt (https://www.predictit.org/Market/1942/Who-will-win-the-Ohio-Republican-primary) seems to think that this is 70/30 in favo[u]r of Kasich. I, on the other hand, think that Trump will win. In re-reading that 538 preview, they talk about how Kasich performed well in Kentucky/Michigan on those counties that border Ohio. I'm not really sure what they're talking about because I checked all the counties that border Ohio in those two states and, as long as I've read it correctly, Trump won every single one of them. Every. Single. One. Of course, Ohio is a different ballgame (Kasich is the Governor, for Pete's sake), but I took a quick peek at the 2012 GOP primary (http://elections.nytimes.com/2012/primaries/states/ohio). In it, I tried to find those areas in the state where Trump has done well. Let me rephrase, I looked for areas in the state with demographics that Trump's done well with in other states. This article helped with that (http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/13/upshot/the-geography-of-trumpism.html), but from what I recall of watching returns: white, poor, and uneducated, are three of the big ones. The 2012 GOP primary interactive from the NYT doesn't let you do TOO much, but you can play with those three categories I mentioned above. So... after looking at all that, and taking into account that Trump is concentrating his efforts in Ohio on Tuesday (cancelled some Florida events and made some new ones for Ohio on election day), I think that HE thinks that his last-ditch efforts in Ohio might push him beyond Kasich.

Going all in (might as well).  Kasich has a strong political campaign built in Ohio. If he can win anywhere, it is Ohio. He has demonstrated in both Vermont and New Hampshire that when he's determined to build a campaign, he does a good job of it.  Kasich has been a relatively popular governor & doesn't have scandals dogging him.  In terms of polls:
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_republican_presidential_primary-4077.html
Kasich has had a generally upward trajectory just as Trump has shown an ever-so-slightly downward trajectory.  There's little reason to believe Trump will over-perform at the polls (though he does tend to do well in open primaries, like what Ohio is holding). On the other hand, there's every reason to believe Kasich will perform as well as his poll numbers suggest.  It will be close, but I feel comfortable putting it all on Kasich.
Kasich has pulled ahead in the polls while Rubio and Cruz have all but disappeared. Will have to keep monitoring as voting begins.
Trump will probably win since he's been in the lead.
Both Predictwise and 538 put JK ahead of DT. The last several polls listed on 538 show JK ahead or tied. Ohio is Kasich's last stand, so I will increase my forecast that he will win.
Upping. I think Kasich's immigration thing will sink him

This is a really tough one. Looking at the RCP polls, Kasich's lead seems pretty anemic. For a guy who won every county but one in his last race for governor, he should be doing a lot better. I think the problem is immigration, and his stance on the "path to legalization." Immigration is the big issue for the Republicans this year, and a great ground game and statewide organization is a handicap if you have taken a position that's at odds with the majority of voters. Kasich's outreach is just telling people that he believes in a policy that most of them disagree with. I think it will be close, but I think Trump will win. People will vote their rust-belt economic interests and their white working class ethnic demographic interests, both of which Trump plays to.

More recent polls from Monmouth University and American Research Group suggest Governor Kasich does in fact have a narrow lead in his home state of Ohio. Over a week has passed since Donald J. Trump led in a reputable Ohio poll. A victory for Governor Kasich in Ohio looks likely, though Donald J. Trump is still a factor here.
Ted Cruz will win the Ohio primaries because he has more influence.

The polls show Kasich getting even farther out in front of Trump: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/. Given Kasich's other advantages in the state (referenced in earlier forecasts), I now think he's almost a 3-to-1 favorite, though the consensus forecast still has him at even money.
Monmouth Poll is confirming Kasich's upwards trend. The republicans have also been pumping everything they can into the Ohio ground game in the hopes of contesting the convention in July.

This one will be a nail biter. While the latest polls show Trump and Kasich neck-and-neck, I'm going to give the advantage to Kasich. Couple of competing factors: (+) Trump often underperforms the polls by a couple of percentage points. 
(+) Kasich is in the best position to pick up voters from other candidates. In the latest FOX poll, 26% of those surveyed indicated that they would refuse to vote for Trump, while only 6% indicated they would refuse to vote for Kasich. 79% of folks surveyed also approved of the job Kasich is doing as Governor. 
(-) Trump's base is more solid than Kasich's.  According to the latest Quinnipiac poll, only 16% of Trump supporters might change their mind, while 21% of Kasich supporters might change their mind.  Links: 
http://www.quinnipiac.edu/images/polling/ps/oh03142016_demos_O33umkp.pdf
http://www.foxnews.com/politics/interactive/2016/03/09/fox-news-poll-kasich-ahead-in-ohio/
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/#polls-only
Trump and Kasich currently tied in polls of Ohio voters: http://www.cbsnews.com/news/election-2016-trump-and-kasich-neck-and-neck-ohio-trump-leads-florida/
I see a lot of good (reliable) poll results for John Kasich
Rubio has started to actively encourage his supporters in Ohio to vote for Kasich.
Donald Trump has been nigh unstoppable in his campaign recently winning state after state; it's only a matter of time before Rubio drops out and Ted Cruz will most likely be forced to endorse Trump.
Latest polls giving Kasich a slight edge.

My rationale for this Ohio prediction stems from my belief that there will be a close race between Trump and Kasich. One would think that Ohio would be a "slalm dunk" for Kasich since it is his state, but according to some recent polling Trump has rapidly been gaining some ground. However, I still think that this will be a narrow victory for Kasich.
Latest polls show momentum for Kasich.
Updating with latest poll numbers from Fivethirtyeight. I personally think it's going to be closer but without more information I've chosen to defer to them.
When in doubt, go with Marist.
I feel like everyone is just voting for Trump because of the way he is convincing them.
Donald Trump has won a lot of the votes already. I believe with his massive support he will also gain Ohio.
Most likely Trump will win Ohio, yet there is a possibility that Kasich will win because he is former governor of the state.

I think TRump will continue winning but Crus has a chance. I bet Rubio will lose and drop out. 
MCP2559

Kasich is neck and neck with Trump in the most recent polls.  Some even have Kasich ahead by 2 or 3 points.  I would imagine that Marco Rubio's plea to his followers to vote for Kasich instead of him could have a small effect, but in a very contested election, it might make a difference. Ben Carson endorsed Trump this week which one would assume helps him.  Arnold Schwarzenegger endorsed Kasich. I think that will definitely help him get some votes.  http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_republican_presidential_primary-4077.html
Kasich closing strong, but bad karma trump anger has a chance to overwhelm the better man in a republican primary ( as, alas, we've seen, time and again.

Kasich is well-liked by moderate republicans in Ohio. However,  1.) Trump has momentum and people know it now. 2.) I'm from Ohio, I know republicans from Ohio, and my gut tells me Trump speaks to the zeitgeist.  3.) Kasich annoyed many of the far right tea party types in 2014. I think they are looking for a replacement.
I'm tweaking this again in favour of Kasich. He's a heavy favourite by 538's polls-plus model and a favourite using their polls-only model; my own forecast falls somewhere in between.
My prediction is based on 538.com polls.

Kasich will win bc it's his home state.
Since my last prediction Kasich's position in polls has improved markedly.

Adjusting in light of the Rubio campaign's latest comments, which shift support substantially toward Kasich. Cruz gets a 'faint hope' mention given a recent CBS poll which put him in a near-tie with Kasich and Trump, but this is probably a two-horse race.
I feel Kasich will win his home state and Rubio, Cruz, and Trump will be fairly close in poll percentages.

Fivethirtyeight.com, using weighted polling averages, forcecasts a 75% probability for Kasich:

i think kasichs numbers will be higher in this primary because rubio urged ohio citizens to back kasich in order to prevent trump from winning the primary
There is a good chance that Kasich will win Ohio given the voting history of Ohioans.

Kasich is leading the polls according to the WSJ.  It's possible this weeks scandals around Trump's rallies will affect him in Ohio just enough to give Kasich the edge he needs. Cruz won Wyoming and Rubio won DC yesterday. Nothing too significant but may show some erosion in Trump's ascent.

New polls again show Governor Kasich with a slight lead or he and Donald J. Trump locked in a tie for the Ohio primary. I give Governor Kasich a slight edge to win Ohio now due to leading in two of the three most recent polls.
Raising JK 25% (lowering Trump 25%). Recalibrating to some of the recent polls released.

NB: no change to last update. Wanted only to provide reasoning why my final judgement was to go aback up to a higher number for Kasich in Ohio.  Influenced as follows:  HT @ECR for point made reference reliability of polls there; @GJDrew on points made reference DT followers proving v vocal but, losing momentum into the voting booth &, somehow ran across @Pythagoras which was much more granular/detailed than my original higher number.  Re-thought all three points, in addition to my initial inclination, in the light of the unruly weekend events. Added them all up &, looked at the following PEW http://pewrsr.ch/1RQaJaD updated research which shows primary voters turning out in record numbers. Believe in this particular case - Ohio - Kasich comes away winner.
Donald Trump has been having successful debate but the votes are going to be close as John Kasich is the governor of Ohio and has a good amount of voters there.

I am raising Kasich from 65 to 69. 538 gives Kasich a 68% chance to win with Polls Plus (which includes endorsements), and a 49% chance to win with just Polls. For most candidates, the endorsements help, and including those in the Polls Plus makes sense. Trump does not have many endorsements, but endorsements have had less effect on this GOP contest than in the past. Trump has pretty consistently performed better than his Polls Plus ranking (but not quite as good as his pure Polls ranking). In the past, I have been averaging the two for Trump. That would give Kasich about a 59% chance. I elevated this earlier after Rubio told his followers to vote for Kasich in Ohio. Last night's disruption of the Chicago rally is putting Trump's hate-mongering tactics in the spotlight. Those last two factors can't be measured in recent polls, so I'm giving Kasich a slightly higher chance of winning than is justified by the polls.
Best opportunity for #NeverTrump to consolidate opposition.  With divisiveness of Trump on full display in St. Louis and Chicago, Kasich has nice opportunity to nudge undecideds to his side.

The current consensus forecast is that there is a 21% chance that either Cruz or Rubio will win Ohio. But it's certainly time (for me, at any rate) to dispense with the fiction that either Cruz or Rubio has a chance worthy of the name. The polls have never favored either in this state, and they now project a less than 1% chance that either will win[a]. Furthermore, neither Rubio nor Cruz have especially interesting advantages in Ohio (i.e., they don't hold elected office there, they weren't born there, they haven't lived there or gone to university there, they don't run businesses that have large interests there, etc.), and Rubio has even told his supporters to vote for Kasich[b]! But the Kasich and Trump match-up presents us with a real head-scratcher. The aggregate of polls suggests the two are in a dead heat[c], though when one takes endorsements into consideration, Kasich has about a 2-to-1 advantage[d]. Moreover, Kasich has a lot of infrastructure advantages in Ohio, which is not surprising given his job title. For example: "An unusual arrangement with the state Republican party and a supportive super PAC loaded with former top aides from the governor's office has allowed Kasich to lay an extensive groundwork ahead of the March 15 primary. 'We're running a truncated, mini-gubernatorial campaign in a month,' Matt Borges, the Ohio Republican Party chairman, said in an interview. 'Do I think all of those things make up a couple of points? Yes.' Kasich trailed Drumpf in Ohio by 6 points in the most recent CNN/ORC poll, 41% to 35%. But a Fox News poll released Wednesday showed Kasich ahead by 5 points. The reality, state officials say, is that the race is largely a toss-up at this point. 'We know where we have a lot of work to do,' Borges said. 'You have a governor with a 77% approval rating. We've gotta remind Ohioans why they like him, what they like about him.' Internally, Kasich's team is encouraged by what they see happening on the ground. Save for a series of ad buys and a few appearances in the state, they've seen little else in the form of an organization from Drumpf in the state. Marco Rubio, focused solely on survival in Florida, and Ted Cruz, aren't planning any stops in the state. In the past few primary contests, including in Michigan, late breaking voters have trended toward Kasich, not Drumpf. A race that becomes essentially a one-on-one battle with Drumpf, with a full week of a coordinated blitz to hammer home why people in the state approved of Kasich to begin with, provides a clear opportunity to rise, aides and supporters say"[e]. That's a somewhat one-sided take, but Kasich's underlying strengths in Ohio are pretty clear. It's true: Trump has been running a lot of negative adds very recently[f], but they appear to involve little that Ohioans haven't heard during Kasich's gubernatorial campaigns here, save the claim that Kasich is an absentee landlord. Will that work? Unemployment in Ohio is 5.7%, and it's been experiencing economic growth over the last few years: "the state had a projected GDP of $526.1 billion in 2013, up from 517.1 in 2012, and up from 501.3 in 2011"[g]. If the state were under water, then the absentee landlord charge might sting, but that's not the case. -- [a] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/
[b] http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-03-11/rubio-tells-ohio-supporters-to-back-kasich-in-bid-to-block-trump - though it's worth noting that at least some are resisting; that won't help Rubio, but it might hurt Kasich, see http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/marco-rubio-ohio-strategic-voting-220666
[c] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/#polls-only
[d] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican
[e] http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/11/politics/john-kasich-ohio-donald-trump/index.html
[f] http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/11/politics/donald-trump-john-kasich-tv-attack-ad-ohio/index.html
[g] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_Ohio
Kasich will win the presidential candidate.

Trump supporters didn't get their daily dose of Trump as the rally was cancelled and it shows a certain weakness that will make them look at what Kasich has to offer, this will lead to a small number of them ditching Trump in favor of Kasich.
Increasing kasich from 60 to 65 based on Rubio support, who is telling his followers to vote kasich in Ohio.

Polls show Senator Cruz doesn't have a meaningful chance of winning in Ohio, and neither does Senator Rubio. No new polls have come in since my previous forecast. I still regard this primary as a toss-up between Governor Kasich and Donald J. Trump, pending more information.
kasich's home state, Rubio and his backers will have migrated to his campaign
The WSJ says that Rubio workers are urging a vote in Ohio for Kasich.  They're desperate to stop Trump.  I think it will play out that way, but I'm really uncertain.

Movement in the Ohio polls has been consistently downward for Trump, Trump tends to underperform his poll numbers, and Rubio threw his support in Ohio to Kasich.  Combined, I'm moving from 50-50 to 70-30 Kasich.

http://www.politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/03/marco-rubio-ohio-kasich-220635
Rubio  supporter should be enough to make Kasich the winner.
Smarter people than I seem to indicate Kasich has a remarkably good chance at winning.  Adjusting pretty rapidly due to very high earlier positions.
Basically going to ride consensus on this one. Too close to call.
Trump with Ben Carson said intelligent things together yesterday. Kasich has good position in Ohio with some problems, I am waiting for a response from Kasich to Trump (after his speach)

While it is very close, I have Trump winning in Ohio. This is solely off of my research on the current polls for Ohio. While this is Kasichs state, I believe that Trump will keep the race very close, and will potentially will the win in Ohio. However, I will find it to be absolutely no surprise if Kasich wins.
It's interesting that the Rubio Campaign is asking people to toss votes to John K.

Carson's endorsement will add a tiny (1%) boost to Trump's odd's in Ohio. Further, the new messaging about stopping Trump where you may be puts Kasich's odd back on par with Cruz's. However, you still have to consider that Kasich hasn't won anywhere. ANYWHERE. That said, neither of them are likely to beat Trump.
still high with little help of Rubio

538 blog has Kasich with a 68% chance.  But, I believe Trump will benefit from the recent debate yesterday where he was not attacked(+3% to Trump, -3% to Kasich).  Yet another good day of press for Trump with a Ben Carson endorsement(+5% to Trump) whom republicans seem to respect and like.  (-2%) Trump occasionally under performs his poll numbers.
With the news that Senator Rubio told his supporters to vote for Governor Kasich in Ohio, this race looks like a toss-up pending the release of newer polls.

It feels like a bit of a mug's game, trying to forecast this one. Kasich has closed with Trump in the polls in the last few days[1], and he (i.e., Kasich) has been a rather popular governor in this state[2]. Rubio's endorsement (if that's the word I'm looking for) might help Kasich a bit too[3]. The party establishment seems to be making more than a nominal effort on Kasich's behalf[4], though - honestly - that's not proved to be of much value so far. However, a new PAC-based anti-Trump add running in Ohio right now does look like it might have some impact[5]. If Trump has anything (other than consistently good polling numbers!) in his favor, it's the possibility of crossover Democrats voting for him[6]. We probably won't have much of a sense of whether they'll make an impact (or even materialize) until the exit poll data starts rolling in. -- [1] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/#polls-only
[2] http://www.politico.com/story/2015/10/poll-john-kasich-ohio-approval-numbers-214549
[3] http://www.npr.org/2016/03/11/470094630/rubio-campaign-vote-for-kasich-in-ohio-to-stop-trump
[4] http://www.bloomberg.com/politics/articles/2016-03-09/the-party-goes-to-bat-for-kasich-in-ohio
[5] http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/10/politics/donald-trump-ohio-trade-pac/
[6] http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-ohio-insight-idUSMTZSAPEC3ATLGUM9

Going up.  Expecting Rubio supporters to vote for Kasich.
will be close but John has home field advantage
Updating. I think Cruz is out of the running in Ohio.

Initial Judgement today had Kasich at 70%; DT at 29%. Look at the Fox poll (March 5-8) as well as the news that Rubio pushed Ohio republicans to vote for Kasich (despite Kasich's rejection) pushed my forecast upwards.  Cruz and Rubio show no evidence at this point of pulling an upset.
Polls have not been very accurate  recently. And the electorate has been volatile as well. Kasich leads in recent polls, but the stop trump campaign seems to have lost momentum. Tough call.
Rubio com dir telling voters to go for Kasich. Stop-Trump strategy 2.0. http://www.politico.com/blogs/2016-gop-primary-live-updates-and-results/2016/03/marco-rubio-ohio-kasich-220635#ixzz42c5paFin

It is a two horse race so I am taking out Cruz and Rubio and spliting the remainder almost equally.  With adavantage to Donald Trump... One lesson from those primaries is that you never win much by betting against Donald Trump. (Yeah, I know I am standing on a fence...) Source: 
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/
Trump has slight lead over Kasich in Ohio, according to polls and news reports: http://www.cnn.com/2016/03/11/politics/cnn-poll-of-polls-ohio-florida/
I feel like Donald Trump and John Kasich will have an advantage in Ohio, which is why I gave them the majority.

Nate Silver has the polling avg. for both tied at 34%, but of the 5 most recent polls, Trump is ahead in 4, and Kasich only leads in the Fox News poll, of which I am inherently suspicious. (Yes, go ahead and tell me I'm awful.) NS overall prediction has Kasich winning, but my gut and locality (raised in Ohio, still live near Cincinnati) tells me that Trump has an advantage. Perhaps this is irrational.

http://cin.ci/1pbTKpo : From Cincinatti Enquirer @ www.cincinnati.com " A Gentlemanly Debate" http://cnn.it/1SyUW24 Increasingly, this vote comes down to whether  Ohioans are willing to cast their "voter take all" for a candidate who will not become the Presidential GOP candidate. This is the fundamental question from my perspective. Generally speaking,  in the past, this state has proved to be a voter block of sound, clear minded people albeit, with a conservative bent. Due in great part, I suppose, to its broad based economy. It too however, has lost momentum, relative to other states in growth terms. That said, Kasich still maintains strong support, so it makes the vote v/ close.  The easy answer, is yes Kasich wins but, just barely. The harder question now I think is : does  overall momentum, flow of information to the voting public, a clear voter discontent & desire to alter the status quo  in the state all add up to take DT into the winners circle here ? These are all variables/uncertainties that aren't readily quantifiable, especially at this late stage.  NB: above-mentioned Q: on whether Ohio voters are willing to cast their vote for someone they know will not become the GOP's Presidential nominee. There is reasonable probability Ohioans will surprisingly vote for being reasonable. Not tossing their votes away to Kasich ( although well respected). Rather, a vote for perhaps hoping that IF DT takes the GOP slot, he will  push for lower taxes, less government intervention in the educational system and, the like.
Kasich showed his cool without budging at the Republican debate, Trump still has strong support, Cruz and Rubio are tagging along in Ohio.

There have been four reputable Ohio polls since March 1st. Trump is leading 3/4 of them, but by slim margins. The most recent poll, conducted by Fox News between March 5-8, actually has Kasich leading by 5 points.  At this point, its pretty much a toss up, but I'm giving a slight edge to Kasich. He seems to have a better chance of capturing voters that either don't know who they are voting for (6%) or may change their minds (24%). Why? Looking at the FOX poll, Kasich is the preferred second choice of 21% of voters, while Trump is only the second choice of 12% of voters. Also, 79% of those polled have a favorable opinion of the job Kasich has done as Governor.  Link:
http://www.foxnews.com/politics/interactive/2016/03/09/fox-news-poll-kasich-ahead-in-ohio/
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/#polls-only

Adjusting to reflect the new Fox poll that shows Kasich leading. Will Kasich continue to advance, or will it prompt damaging attacks on him? It's hard to say, but  (a) I imagine that many Ohio voters would support Kasich if he seemed to be a contender. That creates a self-reinforcing, positive-feedback dynamic. (b) The obvious attack against Kasich—he's a traitorous squish who signed onto Obamacare—is unlikely to be effective in Ohio. His decision was targeted at the Ohio electorate. So I think the polling average is probably underrating his chances.

- Ok, so looking at the exit polls (available from CNN.com) from Michigan, Mississippi, and Massachusetts, and the entrance polls from Iowa it seems like open primaries do NOT favor Trump. It seems like his vote share stays the same from Republicans to Independents. On the other hand, Kasich's vote share increases among independents compared to his vote share among Republicans. This suggests that contrary to my prior belief, the Ohio open primary may actually favor Kasich.  - The latest PPP poll has Trump up 38% to 35% on Kasich, but coupled with the fact that this is Kasich's home state, that he is its governor, and that his ground game should be much better organized than Trump's, he may have the edge. - 538 (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/) has Kasich 37.9% to Trump 35.7% in its polls-plus model, which probably is a more sophisticated version of the above argument. Note that it's polls plus model has tended to underestimate Kasich's vote share and to be pretty close on Trump's.  - Nevertheless, pending further polling, I'm staying at 55/45 for now.
Honestly, Trump has just been so consistently ahead the entire time. However, it's not impossible that someone else might win, so I gave them a small margin.

I have no idea why consensus has surged for Cruz recently. I don't know what the odds here should be, but to me it looks like it's a two man race between Trump and Kasich.  http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_republican_presidential_primary-4077.html I kind of think more things look like they may be tipping Kasich's way vs. Trump (these factors include: a) the logic of strategic voting for MR & TC supporters, b) Trump cracking a bit this wknd, c) JK momentum created from better than expected performance in Michigan, etc). John Kasich, a popular two term governor of the state, has strong structural advantages going into his state's primary. However, Kasich is a relative moderate, and the closed primary may benefit more hard-line registered Republicans who are more likely to turn out for the primary election. Donald Trump has showed strong blue-collar support in states like Michigan, and has a chance to demonstrate his power in the Midwest. Polls plus forecasting show about a 60% chance for Kasich, with his polling lead increasing over Trump in recent days.

Raising Kasich 6 (lowering Trump 6). Kasich had a pretty good night, er, let me clarify: he had a good night for a prospective win in Ohio. On those counties that border Ohio (in Kentucky), it looks like Kasich was doing alright. I might be reading too much into this, but given the lack of polling in Ohio and the fact that this IFP is still at approximately 50/50 (rarely are things actually at 50/50), I'm trying find a little extra value. List of upcoming events:
Mar 6: Puerto Rico 
Mar 8: Hawaii, Idaho, Michigan, Mississippi 
MAR 10: GOP Debate 
Mar 12: DC, Guam 
Mar 15: Ohio (among others) Unless there's a poll on Monday in Ohio, I don't expect to change this much, until the vote in Michigan on Mar 8. I don't think Kasich will win Michigan, but it might give us a good idea of how likely Kasich is to do in Ohio.

Terrible night for Rubio tonight, and a great night for Cruz. Quite some evidence that Trump lost support and Cruz gained it in the last two days in Louisiana - Trump started out way up as the early votes were counted and his lead consistently narrowed as the primary day votes were counted. Cruz seems to be successfully designating himself as the anti-trump. Also, Kentucky precints bordering Ohio voted 33% Cruz, 30% Trump, 23% Kasich, 14% Rubio. I expect Kasich to have some extra home advantage in Ohio, but this definitely adjusts upwards the current poll numbers (30% Trump, 27% Kasich, 18% Cruz, 12% Rubio) to assign more weight to Cruz and less to Trump and Rubio.

DT - leads polling slightly, but polls slightly dated; unclear what adjustment to make based on recent news. 
JK - behind in polls; difficult to see major increase in support (well known in state already) so relying on DT losing support. 
TC - well back in polls, but positive momentum may lift chances. 
MR - polling badly and no sign of positive news to boost support.

Trump is up by 2-5 point in most polls, but he also was up by 12 points in Kansas and all looks like that state is now going to Cruz (results still coming in).  I'd assume Carson's supporters (which were last counted at 5% of voters) will now go to Trump.  But I will still bet on Kasich taking his own state.   http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-ohio-republican-presidential-primary

Giving Trump the advantage.  The next polls may indicate if the GOP's encouragement to vote for DT's closest competitor (Kasich) will change the numbers. From ALM21's Huffington Post link: there are only two polls reported from 2016, a Quinnipiac and a Baldwin-Wallace (which only gives DT only a 2% lead). The Quinn. Data has Kasich at no better than 29%, and falling to 26% in the latest poll.  Trump is stable at 31%, after continuously increasing since joining the race.  Cruz is the fast riser, but is still 10% down in Quinn, and 20% down in the BW (that difference seems to indicate that either 1. the numbers are still changing, or 2. one one poll is off).  Suspect that if Cruz is gaining momentum, not reported in the BW numbers, some of the increase may be coming from Kasich voters - although is is only speculation based on the later Quinn poll.
Rubio and the other do not seem strong in Ohio.

Based on the slope (angle) of the green and red lines at this link, if sustained, JK will be close and may pass DT by the primary.

According to news reports Trump is leading Kasich, but not by much. Seemingly this could go either way ... to Trump or Kasich.

According to fivethirtyeight.com, Kasich has a slight edge over Trump. I really don't see Cruz having any realistic chance, so I'm discounting him in favor of Rubio.

As an Ohio native, I can confidently say... I have no idea. I'll again give my nod to an average of 538's polls-only (DT-JK-TC-MR: 52-34-11-3) and polls-plus (37-42-9-13) formats: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican. In short, it's a toss up between our relatively popular governor and the Donald, but I don't think it's wise to be putting 0s for Rubio and Cruz. While they're definitely long shots, they are both opening up their coffers for Ohio's winner-take-all status, much to my chagrin seeing billboards and ads everywhere. Here's to wishing it would be November 9th living in a nasty battleground state...

After thinking about it a bit more, I'm adjusting my earlier prediction by moving Rubio to zero and giving his 10% to Kasich. The outcome of this question will depend on whether Ohio's primary Republican voters want to prevent Trump from winning a majority of delegates before the convention or not. If they do, then a win for Kasich is their only option, even though he has no chance of winning the nomination himself. Kasich is personally popular and the voters know him well. If Ohio becomes critical for Trump's nomination, I would expect a lot of national Republicans to focus on it too.
will win for his past performance.

https://www.predictit.org/Browse/Group/70/March-Primaries - 61/42 Kasich-Trump http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/#polls-only has Trump 52% http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/ has Kasich 42% Trump 37%

Quinnipac poll from Feb 16 - 20 has Trump ahead of Kasich, followed by Cruz, and then Rubio.  http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_republican_presidential_primary-4077.html On the other hand, I'd say Kasich is likely to get a solid boost due to this being his state and him having a high approval rating (not to mention already having organizational capabilities to get out the vote...).  http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/#polls-only

In a couple of the other "who will win state x" IFPs, I've waited until closer to when the state was actually going to vote -- because SO much can change in a day of primary politics, especially with someone like Donald Trump. So, against my better judgment (ha!), I'm going to forecast on this and the Florida IFP from the first day. To that end, there are some important dates before the vote in Ohio:
Mar 5: Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine
Mar 6: Puerto Rico
Mar 8: Hawaii, Idaho, Michigan, Mississippi
MAR 10: GOP Debate
Mar 12: DC, Guam
Mar 15: Ohio (among others) ~~ Right now, the RCP average has Trump up by... 5 points... but the polling there has been pretty sparse. That average is from the middle of February and there isn't another one unless you go back to late September! (http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/oh/ohio_republican_presidential_primary-4077.html)  Right now, the 538 forecast has Kasich's chances at 42% and Trump at 37%. (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/) ~~~ Kasich has repeatedly said that he's going to win Ohio and, presuming he stays in the race to Ohio (it doesn't look like he's going to drop out now), I think he... I think he probably will. An interesting tidbit: Oct 8 (2015): "Kasich's Ohio approval rating hits record high" --> http://www.politico.com/story/2015/10/poll-john-kasich-ohio-approval-numbers-214549 Republican presidential candidate and Gov. John Kasich has surged to an all-time high job approval rating among voters in his home state of Ohio, according to the results of the latest Quinnipiac University poll released Thursday. More than six in 10—62 percent—said they approve of the job their governor is doing. Kasich, a GOP presidential candidate, drew just 29 percent disapproval. The numbers are in line with Kasich's previous high of 61 percent to 28 percent in August, still within the statistical margin of error. ~~~~ COMMENT: The one thing I think that hurts Kasich is how far away the vote in Ohio is from today. And more importantly, how many other states there are between now and then. I'm pretty sure that Kasich will win NONE of the states between now and Ohio -- not even Michigan. That's going to do a lot do depress people about his chances and it may also dissuade folks from turning out for Kasich... maybe. With that being said, I'm still going to come in a bit higher (that most have) for Kasich on this one.
My prediction is based on 538.com polls.

Most recent poll is 13 days old. Trump with a 5-point lead, but less in the Baldwin Wallace polls than in the Quinnipiac. Trump supporters may be less motivated to vote than Kasich supporters, but their minds are more made up (78% to 50%). Also, Ben Carson's name will be on the ballot, so he may still get votes. If Carson supporters move to another candidate, I think it will split between Trump and Cruz, leaving Kasich out.

I have a feeling that I'm going to regret this. My theory of the case is simple: The people of Ohio will want to back a winner, and Trump will look inevitable. By the time Ohio votes, Trump will have most likely won three of the four contests on March 5th (Kentucky, Louisiana and Maine) and will be set to win big in Michigan and Mississippi. Rubio and Cruz will be able to pick up smaller states, and Kaisch will still have won none. It will be obvious that Trump is going to cruise to the nomination, and most likely prevent a brokered convention. The writing will be on the wall in big gold Sharpie. Kaisch is incredibly popular in his home state, and he mentions Ohio every 5 minutes during every debate. But Trump has a slight edge in polling as of now, and he's only going to win between now and the vote. Nothing succeeds like success. Mitt Romney couldn't stop him, the other candidates couldn't stop him. Most Ohio Republicans will want to be part of this phenomenon, for better or worse. I'm all in too.

I'm taking FiveThirtyEight's polls-plus[1] as my initial prior, but I note that its polls-only data[2] suggests Trump has a 52% chance of victory while Kasich is far behind at 35% (Cruz and Rubio swap places, with Rubio down to a 3% chance of victory). When I have a chance, I'll want to go back and see whether the polls-plus or polls-only data has had more predictive value for Trump's performance in the other primaries. I also note that Kasich is likely to have a ground game here entirely unlike that in other state, since - of course - he holds high office here. That's got to count for something, but I'm not yet sure how to take that on quantitively.  -- [1] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/
[2] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/ohio-republican/#polls-only

I rate this race as a toss up, Kasich is the reasonably well liked Gov of this state, he has a organization in place and since only R's will be voting I would tend to give him the nod here, but Trump is according to polls is neck and neck. His brother governor Bill Haslam of Tennessee, is now backing Marco Rubio.  The latest poll results from Baldwin-Wallace College outside Clevland show the vote too close to call. this a tight race between Trump & Kasich & I'm actually going to give the nod to Kasich despite the fact that he trails Trump slightly in the polls. Trump tends to do badly amongst late deciders & Kasich has home state advantage.

Kasich swept Ohio in the gubernatorial election two years ago. He obviously has the organization to win. Trump has a lot of sympathizers in rust belt states, so you can't count him out. The wild card is that the primary is open to Independents, so formal organization counts for less. Will "stop Trump" independents vote, and will there be more of them than pro-Trump independents?

"in Ohio, where John Kasich has been governor for five years, where the legislature and all statewide offices are controlled by friendly Republicans, most of whom are on Team Kasich, where major newspapers like The Columbus Dispatch and The Cleveland Plain Dealer have touted the governor, his programs and policies in sycophantic articles extolling his virtues as a people’s politician, Kasich trails Trump by five points and maybe more."
http://plunderbund.com/2016/03/04/inflated-ego-keeps-kasich-running-despite-zero-wins-after-16-primary-races/ If you're trailing by 5+ points after 40 years of representing state, that means one of two things 
1. Trump is simply better
2. Kasich is bad and all the other local politicians are even worse And then there:
"Attacking Donald Trump won’t sway voters away from him, Ohio Gov. John Kasich said Thursday"
http://www.toledoblade.com/Politics/2016/03/04/Kasich-not-willing-to-attack-Trump.html#bKo6k6hpEmvJdzrV.99 We saw how well this strategy worked for Bush... Kasich has consistently said that "midwestern" voters will support him, however in Minnesota, he captured only 5% of the vote. In Iowa? Just shy of 2%. In nearby Michigan, polls indicate he doesn't even clear the 15% threshold necessary to win delegates.  Between now and March 15 (when Ohioans vote), the states that will have their primaries all either have Trump polling in first place (usually by strong margins) or else don't have any data available. 
If Kasich wins any delegates, it will be impressive. If Kasich outright wins any states before March 15, it will be little short of a miracle.

The last 2 polls I've seen ended Feb 20 (Quinnipiac and Baldwin Wallace) and both had Trump leading Kasich (+5 and +2). Two weeks is a long time, so I imagine there will be at least another poll released closer to the primary. Will be interesting to see if the recent debate + Romney's endorsing anyone who can take delegates from Trump will matter, but it doesn't look like Cruz or Rubio are a factor. Interestingly, Predictwise has Kasich up 54% over Trump 41% in the betting markets. I'm going to give DT the slight edge for now.
Ohio's demographics fit right into Trump's core.
Trump leading the polls. As usual.

Ohio voters like Kasich. He presented himself well in the 3/3/16 debate. Rubio and Cruz pulled out all their ammo in the debate. Might be enough to overcome the current polls.  Key question will be who is interested enough to go and vote. Trump's supporters have shown the enthusiasm. If the moderates care enough, it be enough for Kasich.

Kasich has basically bet his whole campaign on winning Ohio. As the sitting governor, he has a built in advantage (especially given that I think one of his big hurdles nationally is his lack of name recognition compared to the other candidates, especially Trump). That being said, he is basically even with Trump in the polls at this point. While Trump will spend time and resources campaigning in other primary states before the primary, Kasich will go all out to win his home state.
This is Kasich's home state, though Trump I ahead in the polls at this writing. Trump's performance in the debate in Michigan, however, may hurt him in Ohio and even possibly in Michigan.
